bibl.title: Letter from E.S. Pillsbury to George S. Perkins, April 17, 1908

div1.p: Pillsbury writes to Senator Perkins in support of a pension increase for Mabel Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from E.S. Pillsbury to George S. Perkins, April 17, 1908
div1.opener:
COPY
Increased Pension to Family
of Dr. Lazear.
April 17, 1908
Hon. George C. Perkins,
U. S. Senator,
Washington, D. C.
Dear Sir:-
div1.p:
Information has recently come to me that The
Merchants Association of New York, acting in conjunction with
The American Medical Association, has applied to Congress for
an increase of pension to the family of Dr. Lazear who lost his
life in Cuba through efforts to establish the fact that typhoid
fever and some other infectious diseases are disseminated by
mosquitoes, and that a bill - No. 1168 - has been introduced by
Senator Knox to that end; also one in the House - No. 4375 - by
the Honorable E. H. Hinshaw of Nebraska.

Perhaps you are engaged in doing so many kind acts
that you have forgotten you gave me very effective assistance
in procuring the first pension for this family. Some of the
Senators were then disposed to refuse any aid upon the ground
that Dr. Lazear had gone too far in making experiments upon
himself - that his action savored of suicide and was a bad ex-
ample to posterity. You personally introduced me to these
Senators, and, through statements obtained from General Wood
-2-
and others, explaining the circumstances under which Dr. Lazear
met his death, their objections were overcome and the original
pension voted.

On behalf of the widow of Dr. Lazear, who is un-
married, and his children, I most respectfully and earnestly
invite your attention to this proposed legislation. They are
still living in this State. As you may remember, Mrs. Lazear
was born in California, being the daughter of W. J. Houston
who was formerly in business at San Francisco, but died long
since. I am credibly advised that this little increase would
be very acceptable in helping to support and educate the minor
children and is greatly needed for that purpose.

I will send a copy of this letter to Senator Flint,
and also to each member of the House from this State. You
will be able to explain to them more fully about the case,
if requested, so this letter need not be prolonged.

With thanks, in advance, for the kind attention
which I feel sure you will give this application, and with best
wishes, I am, as ever, dear Senator,
